parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or any other clear identifier.  It focuses on a broader study of political opinions.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its language ("Dumneavoastră") directly addresses a wide audience, inviting participation in a survey.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. While the survey touches upon political opinions, its primary objective is not to directly influence the vote for any particular candidate. The goal appears to be gathering data for research purposes. The post does not explicitly endorse or discourage voting for any specific candidate or party.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>Potentially True.  The post could be considered a form of citizen journalism or academic research, aiming to gather and analyze public opinion. However, the lack of transparency about the research's purpose and methodology could be a concern.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post does not express a personal opinion; instead, it presents a call for participation in a survey.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>2366547817054237</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post promotes a survey on political opinions. While the topic is political, the post itself does not advocate for or against any specific candidate or party participating in the parliamentary elections. The objective seems to be data collection for research, not influencing the electoral outcome.  The post does not violate Article 36 (7) a, b, c, or d because it does not directly refer to a candidate, it is not used during the electoral campaign (although the timing is close to the election), it does not have a clear electoral objective, and it does not exceed the limits of journalistic activity (assuming the survey is conducted and results are published transparently).  The fact that it's a paid post doesn't automatically make it electoral propaganda; the content itself is key.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>INDEPENDENT</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
